Set `$control-border-width` to be `2px` 2. Have two or more buttons in a field with `has-addons`, e.g.: ```html

``` ### Expected behavior The apparent shared border between the buttons should appear to be `2px`, in accordance with the `$control-border-width` value ### Actual behavior The apparent shared border between the buttons will appear to be `3px`

Issues.Title: The more specific padding/margin classes do not override less specific padding/margin classes
Issues.Body:
This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**

I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.4] 
My **browser** is: Brave


### Description

The more specific padding/margin classes do not override less specific padding/margin classes as expected.

### Steps to Reproduce

Add .p-4 and .pt-0 classes to a div
<div class="p-4 pt-0">

### Expected behavior

The div will get padding 1rem all around but the top padding will be reset to zero like if we wrote this is css:
padding: 1rem;
padding-top: 0;

### Actual behavior

The div will have all paddings the same size: 1rem.
more specific class .pt-0 wont override the properties of the less specific class .p-4 as expected from css rules, or frameworks such as Bootstrap or TailwindCSS.

Issues.Title: [FEATURE RQ] Buttons element should have button specifics
Issues.Body: ## This is a feature request for **Bulma CSS Framework**. ### Description Add helper methods to `buttons` element, such like `are-rouded`, `are-primary` where the default for all buttons contained is to be for e.g. round or primary color. This reduces repetition and readability, especially if there are many buttons. This is how it'd look in code: ``` ``` ``` ``` ### How to Implement To implement it's fairly simple but tedious. The simplest method would be to add it to all button color states and the `is-rounded`. This way all nested buttons that use a different color can still override the default `buttons` color, just like with size. For e.g. ``` .button.is-rounded, .buttons.are-rounded .button { border-radius: 9999px; padding-left: calc(1em + 0.25em); padding-right: calc(1em + 0.25em); } .button.is-primary, .buttons.are-primary .button { background-color: hsl(171, 100%, 41%); border-color: transparent; color: #fff; } ``` Another thing to note: Some clarification may have to be made with how `is-toggle-rounded` would work in this example, or alternatively it can be dropped and replaced with `is-squared` or similar. This is to allow removing the roundness of a `button` in a `buttons` nest.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[FEATURE RQ] Buttons element should have button specifics" (#3710)

Issues.Title: Forms > tools .icon should be child combinator
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**. I consider it a bug.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4

`.control.has-icons-left|right .icon` is overreaching, `.icon` should not match all descendants.

The bulma docs indicate the form field icon should be implemented with a `span.icon` as a direct child of the `.control`, but the css matches any descendant.  This can be a problem if you are using a different icon system that also requires its element to have the class icon. 

### Proposal

Forms `.control.has-icons-left .icon` should be `.control.has-icons-left > .icon`

So long as people have implemented according to docs, this minor change should have no negative side-effects.

Fix in saas sass/form/tools.saas (line 183) 
```
- 183 | .icon
+ 183 | >.icon
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Forms > tools .icon should be child combinator" (#3699)

Issues.Title: Migrate from `@import`-rule to `@use`-rule
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **improvement/refactoring**.
<!-- New feature? Update the CHANGELOG.md too, and eventually the Docs. -->
<!-- Improvement? Explain how and why. -->
<!-- Bugfix? Reference that issue as well. -->

Since the [@import](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/at-rules/import/)-rule is deprecated, this PR switches to the `@use`-rule.

Usage of single parts of bulma (from within sass/scss) was also pretty fiddly, because not every file imported everything it needed, so you had to add the imports on your own where the order of imports also mattered. 

### Proposed solution

<!-- Which specific problem does this PR solve and how?  -->
<!-- If it fixes a particular Issue, add "Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER" in your title -->
Essentially I did the three following things:
- replace all `@import`s with the corresponding `@use`s
  - that required some additional `@use` statements that were missing
  - and required to use the namespaces
- switch from [node-sass](https://github.com/sass/node-sass) to [(dart-)sass](https://github.com/sass/dart-sass/tree/1.69.5) to be able to use `@use`
- add stylelint with scss support to make sure that there are no `@import`s anymore

What I **not** did (on purpose):
- refactor anything else
- rename anything
- fix any of stylelints other thrown errors
- update any other dependency

### Tradeoffs

<!-- What are the drawbacks of this solution? Are there alternative ones? -->
<!-- Think of performance, build time, usability, complexity, coupling…) -->

- to reference variables, you are required to use namespaces, which creates longer names, longer lines and larger files

### Testing Done

Projects builds, css output looks good.

Issues.Body:
This is a **documentation fix**. 

Just an update to fix broken link to Trunx: https://github.com/fibo/trunx

Trunx is an actively maintained package that implements React components for Bulma as a thin wrapper.

It has a minimal implementation and provides also a typed `bulma` method and an extendable `classNames` method as helpers to use Bulma classes and custom CSS classes. Those helpers are typed so, thanks to TypeScript, a developer can use autocompletion (even if code is in JavaScript, as long as her/his editor has a tsserver running).

Documentation is not completed yet but the API is stable and it is used by few developers.

Currently supports React (and Next.js) but the `classNames ` and `bulma ` helpers could be extracted and packaged to be used by any framework (e.g. Vue).

Issues.Title: Table is-narrow not working when applied to the whole table (as in class="table is-narrow")
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma **.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** 
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Firefox
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description
I'm build a website using the Jekyll and the [Bulma-clean-theme](https://www.csrhymes.com/bulma-clean-theme/). I noticed that the modifier "is-narrow" is not being applied to the whole table, So it ends up being fullwidth, regardless of setting the whole table to be "is-narrow".

### Steps to Reproduce

Since I'm using Jekyll, I added the table class for the whole table using

```
| Col1  | Col2  | Col3  | Col4  | Col5  |
|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|
| blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  |
| blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  |
| blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  |
| blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  | blah  |
{: class="table is-bordered is-narrow is-striped"}
```  

but the table was still in full width.

This theme has an `/assets/css/app.scss` file that can be used for customization. So I added:


```
.table {
  &.is-narrow {
    white-space: nowrap;
    width: 1%;
    }
}
```

This worked and my tables are now using only the proper space.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Table is-narrow not working when applied to the whole table (as in class="table is-narrow")" (#3695)

Issues.Title: Feature/flex is-gap with sizes derived from initial $sizes values
Issues.Body:
This is a new feature.

### Proposed solution

Bulmas `is-flex` helpers greatly simplifies implementation of flexbox layouts, but a common request is to have gaps between the flexed items. These new `is-gap` classes greatly simplifies this.  
The sizes range from `is-gap-1` to `is-gap-7` and are derived from the initial `$size-X` values. The initial sizes are scaled down 1/3 to range between `.25rem` and `1rem` with Bulmas default sizes.

### Tradeoffs

This does create a slightly larger css bundle - although not a lot.  
It would also be an option to add different gaps for different screen sizes, but this would create an even larger bundle size without adding a lot of value.

### Testing Done

Local testing done with all sizes and settings. Works as expected.

### Changelog updated?

Yes - I have made a new section for 0.9.5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Feature/flex is-gap with sizes derived from initial $sizes values" (#3693)

See demo: https://erbsland-dev.github.io/bulma-tab-box-demo/

### Introduction

In enhancing the user experience with tabbed content, this feature aims to introduce a visually appealing and functional content box situated directly beneath the tabs in Bulma. This design allows users to quickly associate content with the selected tab, as showcased in the demo. It provides a seamless integration between tabs and their respective content, offering both static and dynamic content display options.

### Proposed Feature

This pull request introduces elements for content with pages located beneath the tabs created using the `tabs` element. The new `tabs-box`, `tabs-content`, and `tabs-page` elements provide a standardized framework for adding dynamically displayed tabbed content.

- These elements are optional, enabling tabs to be used without any content.
- The elements can also be used to display static content by simply having a single page marked with `is-active`.
- By utilizing these predefined elements:
    - The script for toggling and presenting individual pages can be standardized and simplified.
    - Themes can style the box where the tabbed content appears.

### Tradeoffs

This feature introduces a few more elements and variables to the framework. Ideally, there should be a standalone solution for paged content where only one page is visible at a time. Such a concept could then be applied to future design elements, like collapsible sections and similar UI concepts.

### Testing Done

- I tested the tabs box with various styles using the default colors and encountered no issues.
- I've set up a demo page: https://erbsland-dev.github.io/bulma-tab-box-demo/
